We provide axioms that guarantee a category is equivalent to that of continuous linear functions between Hilbert spaces. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that use both invertebrate and vertebrate hosts as part of their life cycle. Although the evolutionary origin of myxozoans has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we present the first genome-wide comparative analysis of myxozoans, which reveals that the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite was accompanied by a reduction in genome size and gene content. In this study, we describe a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of proton channels, but the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the demand for food will increase by 50% to meet this demand. In this study, we show that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase to 86% under 4 °C of global warming. These results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. We also show that investments in breeding for heat tolerance are urgently needed.

We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species in semiarid African savanna. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses have widely varying beliefs about the length of the crisis, but many are financially fragile. Many businesses plan to apply for the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act, but many anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, its global distribution and the magnitude of the problem are still unknown. We show that the plastic debris is mostly concentrated in the convergence zones of the five subtropical gyres, but the total load of plastic on the open ocean surface is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the size distribution of the plastic debris, which is dominated by small particles, mostly below 1 mm. These particles are rapidly degraded into smaller fragments, which are then transported to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes. This study provides a better understanding of the fate of the missing plastic debris and is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the elements heavier than iron is one of the most important problems in astrophysics. The study of the origin of the elements is also important for understanding the evolution of the universe. The study of the origin of the elements in meteorites is a unique way to study the nucleosynthesis in stars.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is one of the most important traits in nature. In this study, we show that the ability to provide resources to offspring, such as food and care, can increase the reproductive output of mothers. We also show that the increase in reproductive output is not due to an increase in resource availability, but rather an increase in metabolic power. This study has important implications for understanding the evolution of parental care and domestication. It also has implications for understanding the evolution of human reproduction.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is currently in phase II clinical trials for the treatment of epilepsy, is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn aggregates in a mouse model of MSA. This effect is associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn and with neuroprotective effects in the substantia nigra. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising therapeutic approach for the treatment of MSA. This study provides an in vivo proof of concept of the potential of VX-765 to limit α-syn pathology and to mediate neuroprotection in a mouse model of MSA. This study also provides a rationale for the use of VX-765 in other synucleinopathies. (truncated)

The endothelium is the single layer of cells that lines all blood vessels. It controls vascular function, including the control of blood pressure, the regulation of inflammation, and the control of the exchange of oxygen and nutrients between blood and tissue. The endothelium is a highly specialized cell type that is able to process and integrate information from multiple sources. Here, we show that the endothelium is connected in a network that is highly efficient in transmitting information. The network is small-world, which means that it is both efficient at transmitting information locally and globally. This design is effective for both local and global communication and is therefore optimal for the control of vascular function. The design of the endothelium is therefore highly effective for the control of cardiovascular function.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. We describe the design and implementation of the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 indicators, including many auxiliary indicators that are not available elsewhere. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. We demonstrate that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API are useful for tracking COVID activity, and can be used to augment traditional public health reporting. The data are available for use by the public. We hope that the COVIDcast API will be useful to researchers and policy makers.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical for health and disease. The role of anaerobic fungi in the gut microbiome is not well understood. Here, we report the discovery of natural products from anaerobic fungi, which could be used as a source of therapeutics.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in determining social rank remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait, directly influences social dominance and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as decreased ATP and increased ROS production in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. In a dyadic contest between anxiety-matched animals, microinfusion of specific mitochondrial complex I or II inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens reduced social rank, mimicking the low probability to become dominant observed in high-anxious individuals. Conversely, intraaccumbal infusion of nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3 known to enhance brain energy metabolism, prevented the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious animals. We conclude that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social hierarchy establishment and is critically involved in the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. The ability to design and manufacture mechanical devices with desired responses is of great importance for a wide range of applications. However, the design of such devices is often limited by the complexity of the target behaviors and the material properties. Here, we propose a strategy to synthesize and assemble composite structures with multiple materials to achieve arbitrary and extreme responses. The proposed strategy can be applied to design and manufacture mechanical devices with specific responses for a wide range of applications.

The hemoglobin system is a major target of the heterochronic let-7 miRNA pathway. Here we show that the IGF2BP1 protein, a downstream element of the let-7 pathway, mediates the developmental silencing of hemoglobin in human erythroid tissues. We also show that IGF2BP1 mediates the loss of the transcription factor BCL11A, which is essential for the expression of fetal hemoglobin. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. This mechanism may be important for the development of hemoglobin disorders and may be a target for therapeutic intervention.

Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide. Despite recent advances in treatment, the majority of patients do not respond to available therapies. In this study, we identified a mechanism of cancer cell resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. We found that this resistance is mediated by activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis, which, in turn, activates sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1) and monounsaturated fatty acid synthesis. This mechanism of ferroptosis resistance can be overcome by targeting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway, and we demonstrate that this combination therapy is effective in preclinical models of cancer. These findings have important implications for the development of new therapies for cancer. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common risk factor for heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is a major challenge for the medical community. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). These drugs are effective, but they have several side effects. We show that the three major classes of LCCBs activate STIM/ORAI-mediated Ca2+ entry in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs). Our data indicate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our findings unravel a mechanism of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. This study may lead to the development of new drugs for the treatment of hypertension and cardiovascular diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP has not been successful in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. We also show that the early-seral ecosystem area has been stable, but has declined in two ecoregions, and early-seral bird populations have declined. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. Our results also highlight the importance of continued monitoring of bird populations and forest conditions to assess the effectiveness of forest policies. This study provides a unique opportunity to evaluate the influence of a policy on biodiversity.

Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa (9–15° S). We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that the use of such devices in the hours before bedtime can have important biological effects on sleep. Specifically, the use of electronic devices phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. The role of cytotoxic T lymphocyte antigen-4 (CTLA-4) in the development of autoimmunity has been controversial. Here, we show that the loss of CTLA-4 expression in adult mice leads to the development of a variety of autoinflammatory diseases, including lymphoproliferation, autoimmunity, and inflammation of the respiratory, gastrointestinal, and salivary glands. These diseases are not fatal, but they are accompanied by the development of autoantibodies and organ-specific autoimmunity.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of this order remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 154 genomes and transcriptomes to trace the evolution of beetle genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose. Our results suggest that the evolution of beetles was shaped by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding cell wall-degrading enzymes. These findings have implications for understanding the origin and diversification of beetles and the evolution of plant-feeding habits. They also suggest that the evolution of herbivory in beetles may have been shaped by the availability of microbial symbionts. This study thus provides a new perspective on the evolution of beetles and their symbionts. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may also have broader implications for the development of other protein-based therapeutics. (Show more)

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is contentious. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and CCE: plane flight distance did not improve over the experimental generations in the 2-Model and 4-Model conditions, but did improve over generations in the 1-Model social-learning condition. APOE is the strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) risk. APOE is also a major protein of astrocytes, a major cell type in the brain that is highly phagocytic. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses. APOE2 enhances the rate of phagocytosis, whereas APOE4 decreases it. We also found that APOE4 increases the rate of C1q accumulation in the brain, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with defective astrocytic phagocytic capacity, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. These studies provide a molecular mechanism for the role of APOE4 in AD. They also provide a potential target for the treatment of AD.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is separated from the outer core by a sharp boundary. The inner core is a key part of the Earth, and its properties are important for understanding the origin and evolution of the Earth. However, the inner core is a challenging part of the Earth to study because of its high temperature and pressure. In this study, we propose a new mechanism for the formation of the inner core.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the drug is legal in some states, it remains illegal at the federal level. The legal status of marijuana is likely to change in the future, and it is important to understand the effects of marijuana on the brain. Here, we show that the brain responses to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA), are reduced in marijuana abusers. These findings suggest that the reduced brain DA responses in marijuana abusers might contribute to their negative emotionality and addictive behaviors.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the brain’s mechanisms for comprehending it are poorly understood. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks in the world can be used to understand the human brain’s responses to language.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many scientific applications. However, it is still unclear how to design stable DL methods that can be used in scientific computing. We prove that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs) with great approximation qualities; however, there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a NN. Our results provide a classification theory describing conditions under which (stable) NNs with a given accuracy can be computed by an algorithm. We introduce fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we both prove and numerically verify are stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. Our results provide a theoretical foundation for the use of stable DL methods in scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a prime example of how the human mind can be easily manipulated. In this paper, we discuss a classic psychological experiment that was conducted some 45 years ago and is still often cited as evidence for the irrationality of people’s behavior during the pandemic. We show that the study’s design flaws were not only overlooked at the time but also, in hindsight, led to the study’s authors undermining their own findings. This is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for centuries, and its history is intertwined with the development of modern medicine. In this study, we sequenced the genome of a human pathogen that has been associated with a reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon. We also compared the genome of this pathogen with that of Mycobacterium leprae, the causative agent of Hansen's disease. Our results suggest that the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. This study provides a foundation for future studies of the biology of this uncultured pathogen. (Show more)

Entanglement and entropy are key concepts in quantum mechanics. They are also the keystones of thermodynamics, which is the foundation of statistical mechanics. The entanglement dynamics is a fundamental ingredient in the understanding of the emergence of thermodynamics in isolated systems. However, an exact computation of the entanglement dynamics was available so far only for noninteracting systems, whereas it was deemed unfeasible for interacting ones. Here, we show that the standard quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics, complemented with integrability-based knowledge of the steady state and its excitations, leads to a complete understanding of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain. Our result is a milestone in the study of the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic is still ongoing, and the search for a vaccine is still ongoing. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate that is highly attenuated and can be produced in large quantities. This vaccine candidate is expected to be a valuable addition to the arsenal of vaccines against COVID-19.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and its history is poorly understood. We developed a mathematical model to study the history of plague in Europe. Our model is based on the assumption that plague is spread by human ectoparasites, such as human fleas or body lice. We found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by humans during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), challenging the assumption that plague was predominantly spread by rats. Our model can be used to study the history of plague in Europe and other regions. It can also be used to study the history of other diseases spread by ectoparasites.

The mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, its function in mitochondria of normal and transformed cells is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria and suggests that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This may have implications for the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer patients. (truncated)

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that is involved in severing actin filaments. However, the mechanism by which ADF/cofilin severes filaments is unknown. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF/cofilin in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF/cofilin binds to filaments more efficiently in regions of high curvature, but severing is enhanced by mechanical tension. We propose that the mechanical torque induced by filament cross-linking by ADF/cofilin enhances severing. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of ADF/cofilin in severing in cells and in the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer treatment. Fructose, a sweetener commonly used in soft drinks, is often promoted as a healthier alternative to sucrose (table sugar). However, the results of this study suggest that the healthfulness of fructose may be overstated. Ingestion of fructose relative to glucose resulted in greater brain activation in regions involved in attention and reward processing and promoted greater hunger and desire for food and a willingness to give up long-term monetary rewards to obtain immediate high-calorie foods. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. The results also have implications for the interpretation of neuroimaging studies of food cues and food-approach behavior. The findings suggest that the brain may be more engaged by food cues in a fasted relative to a fed state, and that the brain may be more engaged by food cues in the presence of fructose relative to glucose. These findings may have implications for the interpretation of neuroimaging studies of food cues and food-approach behavior. The results also have implications for the interpretation of neuroimaging studies of the effects of diet drinks on brain and behavior.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a few centuries, and that the genetic structure is influenced by geography. These results provide a better understanding of the history of Madagascar, and they can be used to improve the genomic data used for the study of human evolution. We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others, even when they do not interact in person. This finding has implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society, and for the design of social media.

The presence of chemical modifications in messenger RNAs (mRNAs) is becoming increasingly appreciated, but the impact of these modifications on protein synthesis is not well understood. We show that the presence of a single modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), in an mRNA codon can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. Our work suggests that the presence of Ψ in coding regions of mRNAs can have a significant impact on protein synthesis, and that the presence of Ψ in coding regions of mRNAs may be a common mechanism for modulating protein synthesis. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the impact of mRNA modifications on protein synthesis. (Show more)

This study shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive health and well-being outcomes. This finding has implications for public health and policy, as it suggests that interventions to promote a sense of worthwhile living may be effective in improving health and well-being at older ages.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a well-known phenomenon, but the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. Here, we use a quantitative model to show that the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is driven by the strict energetic demands of the aquatic medium.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. It replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We show that this temperature-dependent growth is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature.

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must respond appropriately to environmental signals. Here we demonstrate that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa detects contact with surfaces on short timescales using the mechanical activity of its type IV pili, a major surface adhesin. These findings demonstrate that P. aeruginosa not only uses type IV pili for surface-specific twitching motility, but also as a sensor regulating surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity. The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. However, the impact of pesticides on aquatic ecosystems is still poorly understood. We show that the concentrations of pesticides in surface waters are high and that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society, and the persistence of the virus in animal reservoirs is a major concern. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer, a common cervid in North America. We also show that the virus is circulating in deer during the winter, when human transmission is at its lowest. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a “One Health” approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. Our study highlights the need for a more proactive approach to contain the pandemic. (Show more)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the causes of the problem, the consequences of the dams, and the solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices. We also propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the search for its cause has been ongoing for more than a century. In this study, we show that soluble and oligomeric forms of amyloid-β (Aβ) are the primary drivers of an early immune response in the brain. We also show that the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ is a significant risk factor for the development of an inflammatory response. These findings have important implications for the development of new therapeutic strategies for AD.

The earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens is still unknown. We present a detailed faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, and show that the exploitation of chickens was widespread and practiced on a large scale. We further show that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe predates the findings in the Southern Levant by at least a century.

The folding of a protein is a complex process, and it is difficult to study in detail. We have developed a method that allows us to study the folding of a large protein in high structural resolution. We have used this method to study the folding of maltose binding protein, a protein that folds in two steps.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates, often described as alarmones, have recently been shown to function in bacteria as precursors to nucleoside tetraphosphate (Np4) RNA caps. In this study, we show that, in Escherichia coli experiencing disulfide stress, the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH assumes a leading role in decapping those transcripts, preferring them as substrates over their triphosphorylated and diphosphorylated counterparts. Unexpectedly, this enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. This work provides a unique example of how a single enzyme can have multiple roles in the same cellular context. (Read more)

Sepsis is a major cause of mortality and morbidity worldwide. The development of severe sepsis is associated with a profound immune dysfunction, which is characterized by lymphopenia, increased apoptosis, and the emergence of myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSCs). We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore T cell function and decrease immunosuppression during sepsis. We found that citrulline, a dietary amino acid, was more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing immunosuppression. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides a potential mechanism for the immunosuppressive effects of sepsis and a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of sepsis. The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. We also highlight the historical impact of humans on the biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to understand the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. This information is also essential for the development of sustainable practices and the mitigation of anthropogenic impacts on the planet.

We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) that is continuous in contrast to all known models of SOC. We show that our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model (cf. Turing reaction-diffusion model), requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. It is also a promising material for strain engineering. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly without phonon instability, and that its bandgap can be fully closed via strain engineering. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. The findings also provide a platform for machine learning of the electronic and phonon structures of diamond. The findings are also of interest to the general scientific community.

The study of the structure and function of peptides is of great interest to the scientific community. The study of the antifungal activity of a structurally unique NCR peptide against plant fungal pathogens is of great interest to the scientific community.

The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the molecular basis of sex differences. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome. We show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm is dynamic and that the proteome of the female reproductive tract is also dynamic. We also show that the proteome of the female reproductive tract is enriched for proteins that support sperm viability. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work will be of interest to the broader scientific community and will be useful for understanding the molecular basis of sex differences in other species. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, to control bleeding. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force application to platelets switches the receptor, VWF’s GPIbα subunit, to a second state with faster binding kinetics. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of VWD. The results also suggest that the binding of VWF to platelets is regulated by force.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the role of viruses in human health has been difficult to study, because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database of viruses, which can be used to study the role of viruses in human disease. The database is available for researchers to use.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. The main reason is that the observational capability is inadequate. This study introduces a new technique, the dual-FOV high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to overcome this conundrum. The HSRL is able to measure aerosol and cloud properties simultaneously. The case study over Beijing shows that the HSRL can provide significant contributions to the understanding of ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. It is expected to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The temperature history of the Earth is a key factor in understanding the evolution of life. The temperature of the surface of the Earth has changed over geological time, and it is important to understand the mechanisms that have driven these changes. We present a method for determining the temperature of the surface of the Earth based on the thermostability of enzymes reconstructed from ancient organisms.

Ion channels are the primary regulators of ion flow and, therefore, of cell function. The activation and inactivation of ion channels are important for the control of cell excitability and the regulation of ion flow. We studied the relationship between the activation and inactivation of the large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel. We found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its rates and extents inversely correlate with channel-open probability. We propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. Our findings may help to understand the mechanism of action of this important ion channel. They may also provide a basis for the development of new drugs for the treatment of cardiac arrhythmias. Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with an estimated 241 million cases and 438,000 deaths in 2019. The Plasmodium parasite infects and invades the red blood cell (RBC) to complete its life cycle. The invasion process is a complex event, and the role of the host RBC in the process has largely been ignored. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the physical properties of the RBC, reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This finding would constitute a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This work provides a new perspective on the invasion process and opens up new avenues for the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Diamond is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. It is also a promising material for strain engineering. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly without phonon instability, and that its bandgap can be fully closed via strain engineering. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. We show that housing mice in low humidity conditions makes them more susceptible to severe disease following influenza virus infection. We also show that low humidity impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in mice deficient in caspase-1/11, an enzyme that is critical for the resolution of inflammation. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings have implications for the development of strategies to mitigate the impact of influenza virus infection in the context of low ambient humidity. (Show more)

The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. However, the neurophysiological evidence for this process is still lacking. Here, we show that the brain’s high-gamma power increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases suddenly whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This merge operation is applied equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity and is consistent with a neural implementation of a bottom-up or left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This process may be essential for language comprehension and production. Future research should investigate whether the merge operation is also present in the language production system.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major regulator of development and tissue homeostasis. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are differentially regulated at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation confers tissue-specific responsiveness to the canonical Wnt pathway. We believe that this is a common mechanism in vertebrates and that it may be used in other organisms as well.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a critical region of the brain that regulates feeding. In this study, we describe a circuit that may contribute to overeating. We show that stimulation of LH neurons that project to the lateral part of the ventral tegmental area (VTA) and to the substantia nigra inhibits dopamine neurons in these regions. We also show that stimulation of LH neurons that project to the caudal part of the VTA and to the locus coeruleus induces eating. We further show that lesions of the caudal LH circuit block eating induced by stimulation of the LH. Thus, we present a circuit that may contribute to overeating and contribute to obesity. This circuit may be a target for the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth and productivity. The ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and bacteria would be a major advance in agriculture. Here, we have developed a system for the control of the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in barley.

We study the impact of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals have evolved a wide range of hearing organs, but they are all part of the body. Here, we show that the web of a spider is a highly sensitive acoustic antenna that can detect the motion of the air particles caused by sound. The spider can remotely localize the source of the sound and even detect the direction of the sound. This is a unique example of outsourcing hearing to an external device.

We estimate the climate and health benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil fuel use. We find that it can save 3.61 million excess deaths per year, which is about 10% of the total number of deaths worldwide. This is more than the number of deaths caused by the 2003 SARS epidemic. The mortality reduction is mainly due to reductions in outdoor air pollution. We also find that aerosols, which are also emitted by fossil fuel use, are the main cause of the global warming. Removing fossil-fuel-generated particles liberates 0.51 °C, which is more than the total warming caused by all anthropogenic sources. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil fuel use is needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause severe illness and death worldwide. The development of vaccines is a critical step in controlling the pandemic. We report the design and characterization of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD protein that is well-suited for large-scale production and elicits a strong immune response. This engineered protein may be used in a variety of vaccine formats, including VLPs, to provide a critical tool for the global fight against COVID-19.

We report on the identification of a ligand for the ALK/ALKALS receptor family. We show that the zebrafish ALK/ALKALS are activated by the secreted ALKALs and that this activation is required for the development of iridophores, pigment cells of the zebrafish. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of the ALK/ALKALS in neural crest development and suggest a role for these receptors in cancer.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the pathogen that causes it, Yersinia pestis, has been responsible for some of the most devastating pandemics in human history. The emergence of Y. pestis from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor is a complex process that has been poorly understood due to the scarcity of ancient genomes. Here, we present 17 Y. pestis genomes from 5,000 to 2,500 y BP, which provide a more complete picture of the evolution of this pathogen. We find that the emergence of Y. pestis was a gradual process, with a single lineage persisting over millennia without significant diversification. We also discover the presence of a flea-adapted form of Y. pestis in Bronze Age Iberia, which suggests a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague than previously thought. These data provide a more complete picture of the early evolution of plague and its relationship to its vector, the flea. (Show more)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 election, women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. The conversion of grasslands to crop production has led to massive losses of soil carbon (C) to the atmosphere. In this study, we show that the adoption of soil health management practices in annual cropping systems can mitigate these losses. We also show that the management of grasslands can be a powerful tool for increasing soil C storage. These results highlight the potential of grasslands to mitigate climate change and provide a framework for the development of climate-smart agricultural systems. The death toll and economic loss resulting from the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic are stark reminders that we are vulnerable to zoonotic viral threats. We developed a risk assessment framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, to prioritize the risk of zoonotic spillover and spread of novel viruses. We validated the risk assessment using data from virus discovery projects and public records of virus detections around the world. The top 12 ranked viruses were known zoonotic viruses, including SARS-CoV-2. Several newly detected viruses ranked higher than known zoonotic viruses. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. Nectar is a reward that many plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is often an important factor in the success of animal-mediated pollination. Here, we show that the color of nectar can be derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We also identify a mechanism for the production of a red pigment in nectar, which is likely to be important for animal-mediated pollination. This work provides a better understanding of the evolution of nectar color and the role of alkaloids in the evolution of animal-pollinated plants.

We present a study of the genetic ancestry of a group of women from Bavaria, Germany, who had artificial skull deformations. We show that the genetic ancestry of these women is very heterogeneous, including signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. We also show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. This study provides a unique perspective on the genetic history of Europe during the Early Medieval period.

The coronavirus MERS-CoV currently causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings provide insights into the origin and pathogenesis of MERS-CoV and may contribute to the development of a vaccine against future coronaviral threats. The lagging strand of DNA replication is synthesized by DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) in the presence of the sliding clamp proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA). The stability of this complex is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. Our results provide a unique view into the dynamics of the pol δ holoenzyme and its role in DNA replication. They also provide a foundation for future studies on the role of pol δ in cancer. The origin of life is one of the most important problems in biology. In this paper, we describe the development of an RNA-based system that can replicate and convert genetic information into functional molecules.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

The clinical characteristics of severe and critical COVID-19 patients were analyzed, and the therapeutic effect of tocilizumab was evaluated. The results showed that tocilizumab could improve the clinical condition of severe and critical COVID-19 patients, and the mortality was reduced. Therefore, tocilizumab is an effective treatment for severe and critical COVID-19 patients.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but it is also a highly toxic metal that must be tightly regulated. In this study, we report the existence of a copper-binding natural product in fungi, which has implications for the role of these organisms in the maintenance of copper homeostasis and the regulation of interactions with competing microbes.

The formation of tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of SiO2, is a unique feature of the sedimentary record. The detection of tridymite in a drill sample of laminated mudstone (Buckskin) at Marias Pass in Gale crater, Mars, is significant because it is the first detection of this mineral in a sedimentary deposit. The presence of tridymite, cristobalite, feldspar, and any residual high-SiO2 glass in the sample is consistent with the sediment source being the Gale crater wall/rim/central peak. The amorphous material is a mixture of precipitated silica, leachates, and possibly a residue of acidic leaching. The presence of magnetite and the presence of post lithification fracture/vein fill anhydrous sulfate minerals in the sample are consistent with the sediment source being the local environment. The diagenesis of the amorphous material is consistent with the presence of a “Lake Gale” catchment environment. The diagenesis of the amorphous material is also consistent with the presence of a “wet” environment.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of temperate and boreal forests, but the geographic distribution of frost risk and the evolutionary impact of frost events on trees are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost risk is strongly region-specific and that the evolutionary impact of frost events is also region-specific. Our findings have important implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of these cells in the pathogenesis of the disease is unclear. Here, we show that the development of colitis requires the dual action of Th17 cells: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These results have important implications for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, and the disease process is also driven by toxic effects of astrocytes. We report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-toxic astrocytes from living patients with ALS. This will enable rapid development of new therapeutics and will facilitate the study of disease mechanisms. This method will also be useful for the study of other neurodegenerative diseases. The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the transmission of the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum. We now demonstrate that Anaplasma modifies the tick microbiota to enhance the ability of the pathogen to colonize the tick. We show that Anaplasma induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which encodes a protein with several properties, including the ability to alter bacterial biofilm formation. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. The findings have implications for the development of vector control strategies for human disease. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The short tail of modern birds is thought to have evolved from a long tail ending in a compound bone (pygostyle) in the group Pygostylia. However, the diversity of early members of Pygostylia is limited, and the origin of the short tail is poorly understood. Here, we describe a new basal member of Pygostylia, Jinguofortis perplexus, and show that it represents the second earliest diverging group of Pygostylia. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases our understanding of the early evolution of the avian tail and the origin of the short tail.

We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of them have the ability to change color. In this study, we describe a new mechanism of color change, which is based on the binding of biliverdin to a member of the serpin superfamily. This mechanism is present in anurans, the group of frogs and toads, and is responsible for the green color of their skin.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. The development of breast cancer is a complex process, and the identification of factors that promote the growth of breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn promotes the growth of BCSCs. Our findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for breast cancer.

The use of fetal animal skins for parchment has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, such as rabbit, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript. These results suggest that the production process allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This process may have been possible because of the tissue-thin nature of the parchment. The results also suggest that the use of fetal animal skins for parchment was not a necessary consequence of the production process.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The age of the extinction is a critical control on the timing of ecosystem reorganization and the development of the modern biota. We present a precise age model for the extinction and recovery based on U-Pb dates from volcanic ash beds. The age model is used to evaluate the role of the carbon cycle in the extinction and recovery, and to establish a precise time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. The age model will also be used to evaluate the role of rate-dependent processes in the extinction and recovery. The intestinal epithelium is the primary barrier between the host and the gut lumen. It is also the first line of defense against invading pathogens and environmental toxins. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is essential for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORα deletion in intestinal epithelial cells (IECs) leads to excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. Together, we demonstrate that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have determined the structure of the spike glycoprotein in complex with the receptor ACE2 at 3.0 Å resolution. The structure of the spike glycoprotein in complex with ACE2 reveals a range of conformational states, which may facilitate binding to the receptor and the subsequent structural rearrangements required for viral membrane fusion. This study provides a foundation for understanding the mechanism of viral entry and the development of therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. The chemical hardness and electronegativity are two central chemical properties of atoms, which can be seen as the first- and second-order chemical potentials. We calculate, as a function of pressure, two central chemical properties of atoms, electronegativity and chemical hardness, which can be seen as the first- and second-order chemical potentials. We find that for most elements, chemical hardness and electronegativity decrease with pressure, consistent with pressure-induced metallization. Furthermore, we discover that pressure-induced s-d orbital transfer makes Ni, Pd, and Pt “pseudo–noble-gas” atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements preceding them (Fe and, especially, Co, Rh, and Ir) electron acceptors, while the elements right after them (Cu, Ag, Zn, and Cd) become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is a step toward understanding the chemical phenomena that occur under pressure.

We show that changes in human demography, rather than climate, are the main driver of changes in global fire activity. This has important implications for the carbon cycle, as fire is a major source of CO2 to the atmosphere. We find that, in the absence of fire, global warming would have been ∼0.11 °C higher by 2100. However, we also find that, under lower emissions scenarios, fire activity may be a key driver of future warming. This highlights the importance of fire in the carbon cycle and the need to manage fire in climate mitigation strategies.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microorganisms is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its symbiotic bacterium, Vibrio fischeri, which is required for the maintenance of a healthy symbiosis. This glycan is released from the host’s immune cells at dusk, when the squid is most active. We also show that the catabolism of this glycan by the symbionts is required for the periodic acidification of the symbiotic crypts, which increases the availability of oxygen to the symbionts and enhances their luminescence. This study provides a mechanism by which animals can regulate the activities of their symbionts. This may be important for the maintenance of the health of the symbiosis. (Show more)

We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. We show how to model the structure of topics in text data and how to use the structure to identify gender biases in topics. Our method is flexible and broadly applicable. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. We hope that our method will be used to identify latent patterns in many domains.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. Our results suggest that the Black Death was the consequence of multiple introductions of the bacterium, which were delayed by several decades. We report the discovery of a densovirus (Parvoviridae) as the likely cause of mass mortality of sea stars (asteroids) in the Northeast Pacific. The virus was detected in symptomatic and asymptomatic individuals, in plankton, sediments, and in nonasteroid echinoderms. The virus was also detected in museum specimens of asteroids from 1942, suggesting that it has been present on the North American Pacific Coast for at least 72 y. This is the first report of a densovirus causing mass mortality of sea stars.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a disease with a poor prognosis, and there is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This study provides a proof-of-concept for the use of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its cultural diversity. However, its settlement history is still debated. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar and found that the island was settled by different groups from Africa and Asia. The settlement history is also influenced by geography, as the genetic diversity is not homogeneous across the island. These results provide a better understanding of the settlement history of Madagascar and the diversity of the island. They also provide a framework to study the genetic diversity of other islands. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants.
