Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to scientists and policy makers. However, despite considerable scientific attention in recent decades, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important evolutionary events in the history of life. It is also one of the most difficult to study, as it is marked by a gradual change in the environment and the lifestyle of the host. Here, we show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle, characterized by the host’s dependence on the parasite to fulfill its life cycle, is linked to a gradual relaxation of functional constraints on the plastid genome. Our findings have implications for the study of the evolution of the plastid genome, as well as for the study of the evolution of the host–parasite relationship. They also provide a new perspective on the evolution of the plastid genome, which is a key component of the photosynthetic apparatus.

The 2015–2017 rainfall deficit in southwestern South Africa was the worst in more than a century. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of such a drought by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. The results also highlight the importance of regional climate models in the assessment of the role of anthropogenic climate change in extreme droughts. The results are of interest to water managers, policy makers, and the general public. The results are also of interest to climate scientists, who will use the results to improve their understanding of the role of anthropogenic climate change in extreme droughts.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and the laboratory has revolutionized our understanding of materials. However, the conditions under which they form are still poorly understood. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this new quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2, provides a link between the laboratory synthesis of quasicrystals and the discovery of a new quasicrystal in nature.

Photosynthesis is the most important process on Earth for the conversion of solar energy to chemical energy. The biosynthesis of chlorophyll pigments is the most productive biological pathway on Earth. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated cyclase enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use BchE, an O2-sensitive [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess an O2-dependent enzyme, the major catalytic component of which is a diiron protein, AcsF. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the O2-dependent enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. Swapping cyclases between cyanobacteria and purple phototrophic bacteria reveals three classes of the enzyme. These data delineate three classes of O2-dependent cyclase in chlorophototrophic organisms from higher plants to bacteria, and their evolution is discussed herein. This work provides a framework for understanding the evolution of this important reaction in photosynthesis.

Neuroinflammation is a major contributor to the pathogenesis of multiple sclerosis (MS), and neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with other neurodegenerative diseases. In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was reduced in both the early and later stages of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) in microglia/macrophage-specific ASK1 knockout mice, whereas only the later-stage neuroinflammation was ameliorated in astrocyte-specific ASK1 knockout mice. We also found that ASK1 signaling in microglia played a major role in generating and maintaining disease. Activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages, in an astrocytic ASK1-dependent manner. Astrocyte-specific analysis revealed CCL2 expression was higher in the later stage compared with the early stage, suggesting a greater proinflammatory role of astrocytes in the later stage. Our findings demonstrate cell-type–specific roles of ASK1 and suggest phase-specific ASK1-dependent glial cell interactions in EAE pathophysiology. The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most extreme in the state’s recorded history. We find that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is due to the influence of anthropogenic warming.

Autism is a complex disorder with a large number of risk genes. Therefore, it is difficult to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a molecular mechanism for autism and a target for drug development. It also provides a model system for studying the role of forgetting in behavior. This study is expected to contribute to the understanding of the etiology of autism and to the development of new treatments.

This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment examining the extent to which people around the world react more strongly to negative than positive news content. Results offer the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date, but they also serve to highlight considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. Insofar as our results make clear the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, they help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. Insofar as our results highlight individual-level variation, however, they highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ homeostasis. In this study, we identify mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein ORAI1 that result in a spectrum of phenotypes, including hematological abnormalities, that are reminiscent of Stormorken syndrome. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The spread of protein aggregates throughout the brain is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases. In this study, we use a fluorescently tagged form of the polyglutamine expansion of human huntingtin to study the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons, causing non–cell-autonomous pathology. We also show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a model for the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The role of bats in the emergence of zoonotic viruses is a topic of great interest. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus, and demonstrated that this protein, MTX, inhibits the antiviral immune response of the host and facilitates viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. The results also provide a potential mechanism for the emergence of zoonotic viruses and may contribute to the development of a strategy to prevent future outbreaks. Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is a critical component of this process. In this study, we identify a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells, and develop a strategy to exploit it.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous motor neuron disease with a variety of neuropathological subtypes. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of ALS patients are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. To explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in ALS, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results suggest that the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in ALS may be a consequence of the disease-related loss of protein homeostasis in motor neurons. This finding may have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for ALS. (Read more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. An optical conveyor technique is presented for continuously loading atoms into the desired trapping positions with optimal coupling to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The early diversification of the flowering plants is poorly understood, and the role of aquatic habitats in the early evolution of the flowering plants is still controversial. The research presented here centers on Montsechia vidalii, a plant first recovered from lithographic limestone deposits in the Pyrenees of Spain more than 100 y ago. This fossil material has been poorly understood and misinterpreted in the past. Now, based upon the study of more than 1,000 carefully prepared specimens, a detailed analysis of Montsechia is presented. The morphology and anatomy of the plant, including aspects of its reproduction, suggest that Montsechia is sister to Ceratophyllum (whenever cladistic analyses are made with or without a backbone). Montsechia was an aquatic angiosperm living and reproducing below the surface of the water, similar to Ceratophyllum. Montsechia is Barremian in age, raising questions about the very early divergence of the Ceratophyllum clade compared with its position as sister to eudicots in many cladistic analyses. The evolution of viruses is often difficult to study, as they are small and rapidly mutating. However, ancient viral sequences can provide important information about the evolution of viruses. Here we present the genomes of five individuals who lived between ∼0.5 and ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level around the world has been rising steadily over the last century, but the rate of rise has accelerated in recent decades. This study shows that the acceleration is consistent with the effects of climate change. The results are consistent with the IPCC AR5 model projections, but the uncertainty is larger.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age in the United States, but that the increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950 than for those born before 1950. This pattern is consistent with the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950, and it has important implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. In this work, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the chemical dynamics of a key enzyme intermediate. This work highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme reactions.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe coronavirus infection with a high case fatality rate. There is a need for the development of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, a broad-spectrum antiviral drug, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial setting, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study also highlights the importance of early treatment in MERS-CoV infection. The data presented here support the development of a clinical trial of remdesivir in MERS.

Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. The food system is a major contributor to greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the majority of people in high-income countries have remained largely unchanged for decades. We show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a large-scale catering operation can have a significant impact on meal selection. This approach could be used to encourage more sustainable diets at the population level.

The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. Here we apply quantitative proteomics to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in a panel of isogenic breast epithelial cell lines stably expressing any of six of the most prominent proliferative oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. What are the effects of vote-by-mail? In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that 1) universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, 2) universal vote-by-mail does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and 3) universal vote-by-mail modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that can be implemented with minimal costs and that it is unlikely to have significant effects on electoral outcomes. The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has resulted in millions of deaths worldwide. The virus has been shown to cause severe damage to the lungs, and the molecular basis for this disease is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion. This work provides insight into the molecular basis of the disease caused by SARS-CoV-2. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis in rats and that this process is mediated, at least in part, by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. We also show that CRF, acting through its receptor CRFR1, triggers signaling of cAMP/PKA, intracellular Ca2+, and PKCε in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide a molecular mechanism for the development of cerebral edema induced by hypobaric hypoxia. They also suggest a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of cerebral edema. We describe some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. We hope that this will be useful to researchers in the social and behavioral sciences, as well as to statisticians.

These results indicate that ETV2-induced ECs can be used as a source of vascular networks for the regeneration of organs. This study provides a new strategy for the generation of vascular networks in the regeneration of organs. (Show more)

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major health problem worldwide. Although the molecular mechanisms of T2D are well known, there is still no cure. In this study, we found that STING is required for β-cell function and insulin secretion. Our data suggest that STING might be a potential target for the treatment of T2D.

Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of human influenza and cause occasional pandemics. Their genome is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates genomic packaging. The existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. We also show that this interaction favors copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This study provides a better understanding of the packaging mechanism of influenza A viruses. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is characterized by the development of atherosclerotic lesions, which are the primary cause of cardiovascular diseases. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a highly dynamic process that is regulated by a variety of factors. In this study, we demonstrate that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP) and transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) by disturbed flow is critical for the development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and suggest a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of atherosclerosis. This study also provides a new perspective for the development of atherosclerotic lesions and the design of therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The economic and ecological costs of wildfire in the United States have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We evaluate government records of wildfires that were extinguished or managed by state or federal agencies from 1992 to 2012, and examine geographic and seasonal extents of human-ignited wildfires relative to lightning-ignited wildfires. Humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the coterminous United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. During the 21-y time period, the human-caused fire season was three times longer than the lightning-caused fire season and added an average of 40,000 wildfires per year across the United States. Human-started wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are an ecological method of pest control, but their direct molecular targets in arthropods remain to be further elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We estimate that the eclipse phase for ZIKV, the time between cell infection and viral production, is most likely short (∼4 h), the median within-host basic reproductive number R0 is 10.7, the rate of viral production is rapid (>25,000 virions d−1), and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. We assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection. Coral reefs are in the midst of a mass bleaching event, which is driven by global warming. The breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is a consequence of the heat stress, but the processes that lead to its collapse remain unclear. Here, we show that the metabolic state of the coral host is a key factor in the breakdown of the symbiosis. We demonstrate that the catabolism of amino acids during heat stress promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates, which in turn contributes to the loss of the coral–algal symbiosis. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a critical barrier that protects the organism from the environment. In the case of cancer, the epithelium loses its ability to maintain this barrier, leading to systemic infections and death. Here, we show that the microbiome can trigger a regenerative response in the epithelium, which in turn can promote tumor growth. Our work identifies a mechanism by which the microbiome can influence the activity of the epithelium, and highlights the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings have implications for understanding the role of the microbiome in cancer and aging. (Show more)

Chemotherapy is an important component of the treatment of breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous. In this study, we show that the expression of the orphan receptor tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that ROR1 expression enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize and reengraft mice, features that may be associated with the emergence of cancer stem cells. Finally, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab is more effective than treatment with chemotherapy alone in eradicating breast cancer PDXs. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (truncated)

The start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is often ascribed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies and subsequent climate impacts. We show that a unique, ∼192-y series of halogen-rich volcanic eruptions, exactly at the start of accelerated deglaciation, plausibly links the eruptions to the onset of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation. Rather than a highly improbable coincidence, the climate changes are consistent with a range of climate impacts, including a shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, changes in Southern Hemisphere precipitation, and a decrease in surface UV radiation. These changes are consistent with the effects of stratospheric ozone depletion.

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and livelihoods, but their importance is often overlooked. Here, we provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also find that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. At the same time, intensive fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. Our data can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge. Aqueous Li-ion batteries are a promising solution for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. The ability to regenerate is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. In the mammalian CNS, however, the ability to regenerate is lost after birth. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This form of regeneration is triggered by physical lesion of a sensory dendrite and is enhanced by disrupting calcium channels and elevating cAMP. These findings suggest that this form of regeneration may be a powerful platform for the discovery of new genes involved in neuronal regeneration. Moreover, our study unites disparate forms of regeneration to uncover fresh molecular insights into activity-dependent control of the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity. The process of DNA recombination is fundamental to the functioning of the genome. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, a model system for the study of recombination. We find that recombination is highly variable across the genome, with some regions of the genome showing no evidence of recombination. We also find that recombination is more likely to occur at the start of genes than in the middle or at the end of genes. These results provide a detailed view of the distribution of recombination in a flowering plant, which will be useful for understanding the function of recombination in this system.

The resting state network (RSN) model of the brain has been proposed to explain the organization of the brain’s functional connectivity. However, the RSN model has been difficult to validate, because of the lack of a method to measure the brain’s activity outside of the context of a task. Here, we used metabolic imaging to measure the brain’s activity outside of the context of a task and to validate the RSN model. We found that the dominant RSN was similar to the default mode network in healthy subjects, but that it was subordinated in Parkinson’s disease. We also found that the dominant RSN was deactivations during task performance, and that this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. This work provides a direct method to measure the brain’s activity outside of the context of a task, and to validate the RSN model. It also provides a method to assess the impact of disease on the brain’s resting organization. This method can be used to monitor the impact of disease on the brain’s resting organization, and to monitor the impact of treatment on the brain’s resting organization.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. Here we report the discovery of a second 5′ modification, the nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) cap. We show that NAD-mRNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in yeast. NAD-mRNA appears to be produced cotranscriptionally because NAD-RNA is also found on pre-mRNAs, and only on mitochondrial transcripts that are not 5′ end processed. These results define an additional 5′ RNA cap structure in eukaryotes and raise the possibility that this 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. This discovery has implications for understanding the function of NAD+ in cells. It also provides a model for the evolution of 5′ RNA modifications in eukaryotes. Finally, it may lead to the development of new tools for studying the function of RNA modifications in cells. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. We show that epigenetic DNA methylation differences at specific loci persist for several years during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) in people with diabetes and are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.

In this study, we show that the expression of the protein, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), is associated with poor prognosis in patients with triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC). We also show that FSIP1 is associated with drug resistance in TNBC cells. We further show that FSIP1 promotes autophagy, which in turn, leads to inhibition of mTOR and Wnt/β-catenin signaling. These findings may aid in the design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with a high social and economic impact. The present study shows that gut permeability is associated with the development of alcohol dependence and with the presence of psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, we found that the gut microbiota is altered in alcohol-dependent subjects, which suggests that the gut microbiota may be a target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is largely determined by the volatile chemicals it produces. These chemicals are synthesized from a variety of precursors, including amino acids. In this study, we identify a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also show that this gene is required for the production of a number of other chemicals, including the biosynthesis of the tomato flavor compounds 3-methylbutanal and 2-phenylethanol. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of the biosynthesis of tomato flavor compounds and will be of interest to researchers in the field. (Show more)

We show that the impacts of global warming on ecosystem functioning are dependent on the thermal tolerance of species. We also show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is more complex than previously thought, and that the contribution of complementarity to the net biodiversity effect increases with temperature. These results have important implications for our understanding of the impacts of global warming on ecosystem functioning, and highlight the need to consider the thermal tolerance of species when assessing the impacts of climate change.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for spatial cognition. It contains a large number of neurons that fire in a spatially tuned manner. The precise organization of these neurons is not known. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that the organization of neurons in MEC is more complex than previously thought.

Flowering is a complex process that is regulated by a variety of environmental and internal signals. In this study, we show that flowering of the host plant is required for flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts. This study also illustrates how the FT protein, which is a mobile signal, can travel long distances in the plant. This study provides a unique example of flowering regulation in a plant system.

Parkinson’s disease is a disorder of the dopamine system of the brain. The dopamine system is also involved in mood and motivation. We show that the dopamine-containing neurons of the nigrostriatum form specialized integrative units within the system. These units, here termed “striosome–dendron bouquets,” are formed by tightly intertwined striosomal fibers and dopamine-containing dendrites. The striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent a subsystem of the nigrostriatum that is affected in Parkinson’s disease and other disorders of the dopamine system. The striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease.

We show that the speed at which people respond to each other is a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.” This signal is used by both people and third-party listeners to make inferences about connection.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the heart rate. The SAN is also responsible for maintaining a normal heart rate in response to changes in the environment. In this study, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of the heart rate.

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its function in plant defense against insect herbivory has not been well understood. In this study, we demonstrate that Si pretreatment enhances rice resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest, by priming the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact to promote plant defense against insect herbivory. This study provides a better understanding of the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of new strategies for insect pest control. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is an enzyme involved in ether lipid metabolism. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the activation of macrophages. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. These findings have implications for the understanding of the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism and may have implications for the treatment of inflammatory diseases.

Language is a complex system that requires the ability to store and integrate information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in neuronal excitability that occur during learning. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical step in the development of plant biotechnology. Here, we report the delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment locus of the DNA nanostructures are important design parameters for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. We also show that the endogenous gene silencing pathway depends on the attachment locus of the siRNA. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will be of interest to the plant biotechnology community.

The world’s largest freshwater lakes are vulnerable to coastal eutrophication, which can alter the structure and function of coastal ecosystems. We show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to large lakes, and that their nutrient inputs may be more bioavailable than expected. Our findings have important implications for the management of coastal eutrophication, which is a growing concern in many lakes worldwide.

We study the dynamics of a chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is capable of providing work to the system only in rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. We show that this bias is a consequence of the underlying network architecture and that it can be understood in terms of the statistical properties of the environment. Our results suggest that the fine-tuning of environmental conditions may be a general feature of complex systems that operate in environments that are difficult to access. This may have important implications for the design of synthetic systems and for the interpretation of natural phenomena.

We show that NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) can cause paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients. We also show that NMDAR-Abs can change the dynamics of cortical microcircuits, which can lead to changes in the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. We then show that these changes can be explained by a dynamic model of cortical microcircuits. Finally, we show that these changes can be used to predict the onset of paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in a mouse model of NMDAR-Abs. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs. They also provide a framework for understanding the mechanisms underlying the wide range of EEG abnormalities observed in patients with NMDAR-Abs. This framework may also be useful for understanding the mechanisms underlying other autoimmune encephalitis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The history of abrupt climate change is poorly understood, and the role of organic matter in such events is not well constrained. Here, we present a multiproxy approach to investigate an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glaciation. We show that the event was linked to an organic matter–derived carbon perturbation and global warming. The event was also linked to an increase in nutrient fluxes and thermocline stratification, which may have contributed to the extinction of the stem group of the trilobites.

The palm oil industry is a major driver of tropical deforestation, and certification is the most common tool used to meet corporate sustainability commitments. However, the impact of certification on deforestation has been unclear. Here, we show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, the world’s largest producer of palm oil. Certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is a promising tool for reducing tropical deforestation, but its effectiveness will depend on the level of commitment by the palm oil industry. Continued efforts to improve the effectiveness of certification are needed.

The exocyst complex is essential for the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential for the functioning of all kingdoms of life. The exocyst complex is composed of 10 evolutionarily conserved subunits, and the regulation of the exocyst complex is essential for the functioning of all kingdoms of life. The small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

In many vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus. In species with polygenic sex determination, multiple alleles are segregating at a single locus, allowing for more than two genotypic sexes. Here we investigate the effects of polygenic sex determination on secondary sexual characteristics in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii. We find that polygenic sex determination can produce modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, including genital morphology, craniofacial morphology, gastrointestinal morphology, and home tank behaviors. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. They also suggest that the maintenance of sex determination alleles may be more important than previously thought. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The retina is a highly oxidative tissue that is challenged by the accumulation of reactive oxygen species-generating adducts of vitamin A. We sought to understand how the levels of iron, which is also a redox active metal, impact the retina. We found that iron levels impact the retina by influencing the levels of reactive oxygen species-generating adducts of vitamin A. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly.

Predators are the foundation of all food webs, and the evolution of new prey niches is a key process in the diversification of ecosystems. However, the evolution of new prey niches is often constrained by the morphological and functional optimizations of the organism. Here we show that the evolution of new prey niches is possible in the cnidarian siphonophores, and that the evolution of new prey niches is linked to the evolution of new morphological forms. Our findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. They also help us to understand how the structure of food webs has changed over time. This is important for understanding the history of life on Earth.

The evolution of the human hand is one of the most important and enigmatic aspects of human evolution. The fossil record of the hominin hand between 800,000 and 1.8 My old is sparse, and the origin of the derived features of the modern human hand is poorly understood. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand from the Middle Pleistocene of Kenya that provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the modern human hand.

Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is a critical metabolic pathway supporting cell growth. We report the discovery of a small molecule that inhibits both human serine hydroxymethyltransferase 1 and 2 (SHMT1/2) enzymes. We also report the discovery of a new mechanism of cancer cell sensitivity to SHMT inhibition, which is rooted in defective glycine import. This work provides a foundation for the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics. This work also provides a foundation for the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics.

This study provides evidence that deforestation can have negative impacts on people’s diets and dietary vitamin A adequacy. The results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. The results also highlight the need to consider the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals, particularly in rural areas of low- and middle-income countries.

Modern farm machinery is a key driver of food production, but its use has come at the cost of subsoil compaction. We show that the increase in mechanization has led to a significant increase in subsoil compaction risk, which is now widespread over 20% of arable land. We also show that the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, suggesting that unconstrained roaming of these giants would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles. Our results highlight the need for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. This will be particularly important in the context of climate change, which is expected to increase the risk of subsoil compaction. Our results also suggest that the ecological strategies of sauropods, which roamed the Earth without compaction, may have been key to their success. (Show more)
